info.title: Starting, switching and terminating a &gnome; Desktop session

abstract.para: Learn how to log in to &gnome; Desktop, and how switch, pause or finish the session.

section.title: Starting a session
section.para: When starting your &productname; system, you first see a login screen as all users must authenticate to start a session. The authentication step helps protect your personal information and data from unauthorized access.

step.para: In the login screen, select your user name.
If your user name is not listed, click Not listed?. Then enter your user name and click Next.
Enter your password and confirm with .

note.title: Enabling Auto Login
note.para: If a computer is used by a single person only, it is possible to enable Auto Login for this particular user at system start. This can save time, but also impacts account security. Auto Login can be enabled or disabled during installation or at any time using the &yast; User and Group Management module. For security reasons, Auto Login is not recommended.

section.title: Switching the session type
section.para: On &productname; you can choose between the session types described above at .
To try one of the additional &gnome; session configurations or another desktop environment, follow the steps below.

step.para: On the login screen, click your user name or enter it, as you normally would.
To change the session type, click the cog wheel icon in the lower right corner. A menu appears.
From the menu, select one of the entries. Depending on your configuration there may be different choices.
Enter your password into the text box and confirm with .

section.para: After switching to another session type once, the chosen session becomes your default session. To switch back, repeat the steps above.

section.title: Pausing or finishing your session
section.para: To pause or close your session, open the System menu in the upper-right corner of the top bar, click the Power Off button and choose one of the options listed.

formalpara.para: Pause your session and put the computer into a state where it consumes a minimal amount of energy. Suspend mode can be configured to lock your screen, so nobody can look at or change your work. Waking up the computer is generally much quicker than a full computer start.

listitem.para: This mode is also known as suspend-to-RAM, sleep or standby mode.

formalpara.para: Finish the current session and restart the computer. Restarting is necessary to apply the system updates.
Finish the current session and turn off the computer.

formalpara.title: Log Out or Switch User
formalpara.para: Finish the current session, but leave the computer on, so other users can log in. This option is only available if you have more than one user account on your system.

step.para: To lock the screen, open the System menu in the upper-right corner of the top bar and click the padlock icon.

result.para: When you lock your screen, a curtain with a clock appears first. After a certain amount of time, the screen turns black.

step.para: To unlock the screen, move the mouse or press a key to display the locked screen dialog. Enter your password and press to unlock the screen.

note.title: Option only available on multiuser system
note.para: The Log Out and Switch User entries only appear in the menu if you have more than one user account on your system.

step.para: Click the System menu in the upper-right corner of the top bar and click the Power Off button to open the menu.
Select one of the following options:

listitem.para: Logs you out of the current session and returns you to the Login screen.
Suspends your session, allowing another user to log in and use the computer.

section.title: Restarting or shutting down the computer

step.para: Click the System menu in the upper-right corner of the top bar and click the Power Off button to open the menu.
Select one of the following options:

listitem.para: Pauses your session and puts the computer into a state where it consumes a minimal amount of energy. Suspend mode can be configured to lock your screen, so nobody can look at or change your work. Waking up the computer is generally much quicker than a full computer start.
Logs you out of the current session, then restarts the computer.
Logs you out of the current session, then turns off the computer.
